title: How to Make a Flower from a Plastic Egg Carton

steps.headline: Separate and cut out each cup from a plastic egg carton.
Make a hole in the center of the egg carton piece by a pressing a pin through it from the inside.
steps.description: Once you've made the hole, push the toothpick through the pinhole. This forms both the stem of the flower and provides the holding piece for when shaping the petals with heat.

steps.headline: Ensure that you're in a well-ventilated area for this step.
steps.description:
Also remove anything that is flammable away from the workspace area, then light the candle. Working carefully over the candle, start to shape the form of each flower that you're creating, using the candle heat to melt the petals into an appropriate form. Don't actually touch the flame or the plastic will burn – just aim the flower close enough for the heat to melt it. The following photos show a range of petal possibilities created just by moving the flower piece carefully over the candle flame: {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/19/Tpf3_800.JPG/460px-Tpf3_800.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/19/Tpf3_800.JPG/760px-Tpf3_800.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

steps.headline: Cover the stem in masking tape.
steps.description:
This tape is to prevent the stem from being spray-painted in the next step. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7a/Tpf8_284.JPG/460px-Tpf8_284.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7a/Tpf8_284.JPG/760px-Tpf8_284.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

steps.headline: Color each flower.
steps.description: Using the spray paint in the color of your choice, gently spray each flower all over. Again, ensure that this is done in a well-ventilated space and be sure to cover the workspace adequately to prevent possible staining.

steps.headline: Use another toothpick to remove the tape off each stem after the paint has dried.
Create the center of the flower using three dimensional paint.
steps.description:
Dab a small amount of paint into the center of the flower and the results should look as follows: {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d2/Tpf11_833.JPG/460px-Tpf11_833.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d2/Tpf11_833.JPG/760px-Tpf11_833.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"

tyn: Egg pack (polyethylene terephthalate (PETE); if you don't receive eggs in such a pack regularly, you may be able to use Easter egg containers instead
Spray paint (any color you like) – non-toxic if using decoration with food
3D paint (dimensional fabric paint) – non-toxic if using decoration with food
text:
Separate and cut out each cup from a plastic egg carton. Decide which flower you're going to make, either the daisy or the poppy: {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/20/Tpf2_233.JPG/460px-Tpf2_233.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/2/20/Tpf2_233.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":346,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":571.5397082658022,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} Daisy: Cut each cup into "equal eighths" to make the petals. Cut the end of each petal with shears to make an edge. Poppy: Don't cut. Simply cutting away the plastic egg holder from the egg carton will allow this piece to open up enough to appear like the flower already. Make a hole in the center of the egg carton piece by a pressing a pin through it from the inside. Once you've made the hole, push the toothpick through the pinhole. This forms both the stem of the flower and provides the holding piece for when shaping the petals with heat. Ensure that you're in a well-ventilated area for this step. Also remove anything that is flammable away from the workspace area, then light the candle. Working carefully over the candle, start to shape the form of each flower that you're creating, using the candle heat to melt the petals into an appropriate form. Don't actually touch the flame or the plastic will burn – just aim the flower close enough for the heat to melt it. The following photos show a range of petal possibilities created just by moving the flower piece carefully over the candle flame: {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/19/Tpf3_800.JPG/460px-Tpf3_800.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/19/Tpf3_800.JPG/760px-Tpf3_800.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/01/Tpf4_162.JPG/460px-Tpf4_162.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/01/Tpf4_162.JPG/759px-Tpf4_162.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":347,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":572.5333333333333,"licensing":"

"} Cover the stem in masking tape. This tape is to prevent the stem from being spray-painted in the next step. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7a/Tpf8_284.JPG/460px-Tpf8_284.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7a/Tpf8_284.JPG/760px-Tpf8_284.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

"}The finished stem covers. Color each flower. Using the spray paint in the color of your choice, gently spray each flower all over. Again, ensure that this is done in a well-ventilated space and be sure to cover the workspace adequately to prevent possible staining. Use another toothpick to remove the tape off each stem after the paint has dried. Create the center of the flower using three dimensional paint. Dab a small amount of paint into the center of the flower and the results should look as follows: {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d2/Tpf11_833.JPG/460px-Tpf11_833.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d2/Tpf11_833.JPG/760px-Tpf11_833.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"

"}The poppy center. Finish up. The flowers are now ready to be used as wished. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/ca/Tpf13_751.JPG/460px-Tpf13_751.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/ca/Tpf13_751.JPG/759px-Tpf13_751.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":461,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":761.3595706618962,"licensing":"

sentences: Separate and cut out each cup from a plastic egg carton.
Cut the end of each petal with shears to make an edge.
Poppy: Don't cut.
Simply cutting away the plastic egg holder from the egg carton will allow this piece to open up enough to appear like the flower already.
Make a hole in the center of the egg carton piece by a pressing a pin through it from the inside.
Once you've made the hole, push the toothpick through the pinhole.
This forms both the stem of the flower and provides the holding piece for when shaping the petals with heat.
Ensure that you're in a well-ventilated area for this step.
Also remove anything that is flammable away from the workspace area, then light the candle.
Working carefully over the candle, start to shape the form of each flower that you're creating, using the candle heat to melt the petals into an appropriate form.
Don't actually touch the flame or the plastic will burn – just aim the flower close enough for the heat to melt it.

The following photos show a range of petal possibilities created just by moving the flower piece carefully over the candle flame: {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/19/Tpf3_800.JPG/460px-Tpf3_800.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/19/Tpf3_800.JPG/760px-Tpf3_800.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons

"} Cover the stem in masking tape.
This tape is to prevent the stem from being spray-painted in the next step.

{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7a/Tpf8_284.JPG/460px-Tpf8_284.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7a/Tpf8_284.JPG/760px-Tpf8_284.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image by: Uploader

"}The finished stem covers.
Color each flower.
Using the spray paint in the color of your choice, gently spray each flower all over.
Again, ensure that this is done in a well-ventilated space and be sure to cover the workspace adequately to prevent possible staining.
Use another toothpick to remove the tape off each stem after the paint has dried.
Create the center of the flower using three dimensional paint.

Dab a small amount of paint into the center of the flower and the results should look as follows: {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d2/Tpf11_833.JPG/460px-Tpf11_833.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d2/Tpf11_833.JPG/760px-Tpf11_833.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"
